query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 O Simon mago, o miseri seguaci 2 che le cose di Dio, che di bontate 3 deon essere spose, e voi rapaci
4 per oro e per argento avolterate, 5 or convien che per voi suoni la tromba, 6 però che ne la terza bolgia state.
query.result:
**English:**
1 O Simon Magus, O wretched followers, 2 who the things of God, which ought to be brides of goodness, 3 you make harlots,
4 and for gold and silver you defile them, 5 now it is fitting that the trumpet sound for you, 6 because you are in the third chasm.
**Old English:**
1 Eala Simon Magus, eala earme folgeras, 2 ðe ða Godes ðing, ðe sceoldon beon bryda godnesse, 3 ge maciað to strumpetum,
4 and for golde and for seolfre ge besmitad, 5 nu gebyreð ðæt for eow ðe byme blawe, 6 forðæm ðe ge on ðam ðriddan cwyldme standað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Già eravamo, a la seguente tomba, 8 montati de lo scoglio in quella parte 9 ch’a punto sovra mezzo ’l fosso piomba.
query.result:
**English:**
7 We were already, at the next tomb, 8 climbed up from the cliff on that side 9 which plumbs down exactly over the middle of the ditch.
**Old English:**
7 We wæron ða, æt ðære fyligendan byrgene, 8 astigende ðæs stanes on ðære healfe 9 ðe ðone dic ofer midne ðone weall oferhlifað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 O somma sapïenza, quanta è l’arte 11 che mostri in cielo, in terra e nel mal mondo, 12 e quanto giusto tua virtù comparte!
13 Io vidi per le coste e per lo fondo 14 piena la pietra livida di fóri, 15 d’un largo tutti e ciascun era tondo.
query.result:
**English:**
10 O supreme wisdom, how great is the art 11 that you show in heaven, on earth, and in the evil world, 12 and how justly your power is shared!
13 I saw along the slopes and at the bottom 14 the livid stone full of holes, 15 each one of them large and round.
**Old English:**
10 Eala, ðu mæste wisdom, hu micel is ðin cræft, 11 ðe ðu æteowast on heofonum and on eorðan and on ðam wonnan middangearde, 12 and hu rihtwislice ðin mægen todælst!
13 Ic geseah ðurh ða sidan and ðurh ðone grund 14 ða liðan stanas fulle ðara holenra ðinga, 15 ða wæron ealle ða micelan and ða lytlan ymbtrym.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Fuor de la bocca a ciascun soperchiava 23 d’un peccator li piedi e de le gambe 24 infino al grosso, e l’altro dentro stava.
query.result:
**English:**
22 Out of the mouth of each one there projected 23 the feet and legs of a sinner 24 up to the thick part of the thigh, and the rest of him was inside.
**Old English:**
22 Uton ðæs muðes æghwylcum oferfleow 23 synfulles mannes fet and scancan 24 oð ðone ðiccan þeo, and ðæt oðer innan wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Le piante erano a tutti accese intrambe; 26 per che sì forte guizzavan le giunte, 27 che spezzate averien ritorte e strambe.
query.result:
**English:**
25 Both of the trees were alight at the top; 26 because of which the joints quivered so strongly, 27 that they would have broken twisted and straight withes.
**Old English:**
25 Þa wæron begen ða treow on ðam tope onæled; 26 for ðam ðe ða gewrixle swiðe gryrelice beofodon, 27 ðæt hi ða wyððan and ða stranglican ða wrixendlican abræcon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Qual suole il fiammeggiar de le cose unte 29 muoversi pur su per la strema buccia, 30 tal era lì dai calcagni a le punte.
query.result:
**English:**
28 As the flickering of oily things is wont to move 29 upward over the outermost surface, 30 so it was there from the heels to the toes.
**Old English:**
28 Swa swa ðæs ligeðes liexan sceal 29 ofer ða hean lyft hyrstum andwlitan, 30 swa wæs ðær eac of heora fotum to ðæm heafde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 «Chi è colui, maestro, che si cruccia 32 guizzando più che li altri suoi consorti», 33 diss’ io, «e cui più roggia fiamma succia?».
query.result:
**English:**
31 "Who is that, master, who writhes 32 more than the others, flickering," 33 I said, "and whom a redder flame devours?"
**Old English:**
31 "Hwa is se ðe ðær swiðost wrixleð 32 bærnende beorhtra ðonne his geferan," 33 cwæð ic, "and ðone ðe ðe readra lig 34 swelgeð and sweleð?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Ed elli a me: «Se tu vuo’ ch’i’ ti porti 35 là giù per quella ripa che più giace, 36 da lui saprai di sé e de’ suoi torti».
query.result:
**English:**
34 And he to me: "If you wish for me to carry you 35 down there by that bank which slopes the most, 36 from him you will learn about himself and his evil deeds."
**Old English:**
34 And he to me: "Gif ðu wylt ðæt ic ðe læde 35 niðer of ðære clife ðe steapre is, 36 ðu miht ðær fram him leornian his sawle lyre."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 E io: «Tanto m’è bel, quanto a te piace: 38 tu se’ segnore, e sai ch’i’ non mi parto 39 dal tuo volere, e sai quel che si tace».
query.result:
**English:**
37 And I: "It pleases me as much as it pleases you: 38 you are the lord, and you know that I do not depart 39 from your will, and you know what is unspoken."
**Old English:**
37 And ic: "Swa me leof is swa ðe licað: 38 ðu eart hlaford, and ðu wast ðæt ic ne wende 39 fram ðinum willan, and ðu wast ðæt ðe man ðigað."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Allor venimmo in su l’argine quarto; 41 volgemmo e discendemmo a mano stanca 42 là giù nel fondo foracchiato e arto.
query.result:
**English:**
40 Then we came to the fourth bank; 41 we turned and descended on the left hand 42 down there to the perforated and narrow bottom.
**Old English:**
40 Þa com we to ðam feorðan wal 41 we urnon and stigon niðer on ða wynstran hond 42 þær niðer on ðam grunde ðe wæs hol and nearu.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Lo buon maestro ancor de la sua anca 44 non mi dipuose, sì mi giunse al rotto 45 di quel che si piangeva con la zanca.
query.result:
**English:**
43 The good master still did not set me down from his hip, 44 thus he brought me to the edge 45 of what was being lamented with the leg.
**Old English:**
43 Se goda lareow ða giet ne asette 44 of his sidan, ac me ða gelædde 45 to ðæs ðe ðær weop wæs mid ðære sceoncan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 «O qual che se’ che ’l di sù tien di sotto, 47 anima trista come pal commessa», 48 comincia’ io a dir, «se puoi, fa motto».
query.result:
**English:**
46 "O whoever you are, who hold the day beneath you, 47 a sorrowful soul, as pale as someone condemned," 48 I began to say, "if you can, speak."
**Old English:**
46 "Eala ðu ðe ðone dæg ofer ðe hæfst, 47 earmlic sawl, blac and forwærgð," 48 ongan ic ða sprecan, "gif ðu meaht, saga sum word."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Io stava come ’l frate che confessa 50 lo perfido assessin, che, poi ch’è fitto, 51 richiama lui per che la morte cessa.
query.result:
**English:**
49 I stood like the friar who confesses 50 the treacherous assassin who, after he is stabbed, 51 calls him back so that death may cease.
**Old English:**
49 Ic stód swá se bróðor ðe andetnysse 50 ðone morðor ðone mánscaðan, ðe, siððan he gefæstnad wæs, 51 eft clypað hine ðæt se deað geswíce.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Ed el gridò: «Se’ tu già costì ritto, 53 se’ tu già costì ritto, Bonifazio? 54 Di parecchi anni mi mentì lo scritto.
query.result:
**English:**
52 And he cried out: "Are you already standing there, 53 are you already standing there, Boniface? 54 The inscription lied to me by several years.
**Old English:**
52 And he cleopode: "Eart ðu nu ðær rihte, 53 eart ðu nu ðær rihte, Bonifacius? 54 Fela geara me leas spel bodode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 Se’ tu sì tosto di quell’ aver sazio 56 per lo qual non temesti tòrre a ’nganno 57 la bella donna, e poi di farne strazio?».
query.result:
**English:**
55 Are you so quickly sated with that wealth 56 for which you did not fear to take by deceit 57 the beautiful lady, and then to make her suffer?
**Old English:**
55 Eart ðu swa hrædlice ðæs medes sæd 56 ðurh ðone ðu ne ondrede ðe to tienne 57 ða fægeran wif, and syððan wyrsan?

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Tal mi fec’ io, quai son color che stanno, 59 per non intender ciò ch’è lor risposto, 60 quasi scornati, e risponder non sanno.
query.result:
**English:**
58 Thus I did, like those who stand still, 59 not understanding what is answered to them, 60 almost scorned, and they do not know how to answer.
**Old English:**
58 Swa dyde ic, swa ða ðe ðær stille standað, 59 forðæm ðe hi ne ongieton ðæt ðe him mon andwyrde, 60 swilce hi wæron gescynde, and ne cunnon andsware.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Allor Virgilio disse: «Dilli tosto: 62 “Non son colui, non son colui che credi”»; 63 e io rispuosi come a me fu imposto.
query.result:
**English:**
61 Then Virgil said: "Tell him quickly: 62 'I am not he, I am not he whom you think'"; 63 and I answered as I was instructed.
**Old English:**
61 Þa cwæð Virgilius: "Saga him hraðe: 62 'Nis ic se, nis ic se ðe ðu wēnst'"; 63 and ic andwyrde swa me beboden wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Per che lo spirto tutti storse i piedi; 65 poi, sospirando e con voce di pianto, 66 mi disse: «Dunque che a me richiedi?
67 Se di saper ch’i’ sia ti cal cotanto, 68 che tu abbi però la ripa corsa, 69 sappi ch’i’ fui vestito del gran manto;
70 e veramente fui figliuol de l’orsa, 71 cupido sì per avanzar li orsatti, 72 che sù l’avere e qui me misi in borsa.
query.result:
**English:**
64 Because of which the spirit twisted all its feet; 65 then, sighing and with a voice of weeping, 66 it said to me: "So what do you ask of me?
67 If you are so eager to know who I am, 68 that you have run the bank for this reason, 69 know that I was clothed in the great mantle;
70 and truly I was the son of the bear, 71 so eager to surpass the bear cubs, 72 that I put money and myself in my purse up there.
**Old English:**
64 For ðæm ðe ðone gast ealle gewende his fet; 65 ða, siccende and mid wependre stefne, 66 cwæð to me: "Hwi ðu me ðus biddest?
67 Gif ðe ðincol is ðæt ðu wite hwa ic wæs, 68 ðæt ðu ðæs ofer ðisne brerd geweorhtest, 69 wite ðæt ic wæs on ðam miclan reaf gescryd;
70 and ic wæs soðlice ðæs beran bearn, 71 swa geornful ðæt ic ða bearn ofercome, 72 ðæt ic ðær uppe feoh and me sylfne on bosme dyde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Di sotto al capo mio son li altri tratti 74 che precedetter me simoneggiando, 75 per le fessure de la pietra piatti.
query.result:
**English:**
73 Beneath my head are the others dragged down, 74 who preceded me in following Simon, 75 flattened in the fissures of the rock.
**Old English:**
73 Be neðan minum heafde synd ða oðre atogene, 74 ða ðe me ær simoniendum foreeodon, 75 on ðæs stænes clifum geflæste.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Là giù cascherò io altresì quando 77 verrà colui ch’i’ credea che tu fossi, 78 allor ch’i’ feci ’l sùbito dimando.
query.result:
**English:**
76 There I shall fall as well when 77 he comes whom I believed you to be, 78 then when I made the sudden demand.
**Old English:**
76 Þær ic sceal gefeallan eac swilce 77 ðonne cymeð se ðe ic wende ðæt ðu wære, 78 ða ða ic ðone hradegan andsware sealde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Ma più è ’l tempo già che i piè mi cossi 80 e ch’i’ son stato così sottosopra, 81 ch’el non starà piantato coi piè rossi:
82 ché dopo lui verrà di più laida opra, 83 di ver’ ponente, un pastor sanza legge, 84 tal che convien che lui e me ricuopra.
query.result:
**English:**
79 But the time is already longer that I have worn out my feet 80 and that I have been so upside down, 81 that he will not stand planted with red feet:
82 for after him will come a more wicked deed, 83 from the true west, a shepherd without law, 84 such that it is necessary that he and I be covered up.
**Old English:**
79 Ac ma is ðæs tíman lengre ðe ic míne fét gewearg 80 and ðe ic wæs swá oferworpen, 81 ðæt he ne stent gefæstnod mid ðám rédan fótum:
82 forðám ðe æfter him cymð láðre weorc, 83 of ðám sóðan westan, hyrde bútan á, 84 swylc ðæt hit is neod ðæt he and ic beon oferwrigen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Nuovo Iasón sarà, di cui si legge 86 ne’ Maccabei; e come a quel fu molle 87 suo re, così fia lui chi Francia regge».
query.result:
**English:**
85 A new Jason he will be, of whom one reads 86 in Maccabees; and as to him was gentle 87 his king, so to him will be he who rules France.
**Old English:**
85 Niwe Iason he bið, ðæs mon mæg rædan 86 on Machabeiscum; and swa ðam wæs milde 87 his cyning, swa him bið se ðe Francena weold.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Io non so s’i’ mi fui qui troppo folle, 89 ch’i’ pur rispuosi lui a questo metro: 90 «Deh, or mi dì: quanto tesoro volle
91 Nostro Segnore in prima da san Pietro 92 ch’ei ponesse le chiavi in sua balìa? 93 Certo non chiese se non “Viemmi retro”.
query.result:
**English:**
88 I do not know if I was too mad here, 89 for I answered him in this manner: 90 "Tell me, how much treasure did our Lord demand 91 from Saint Peter before he entrusted him with the keys? 92 Surely he asked nothing more than 'Follow me'."
**Old English:**
88 Ic nat gif ic wæs her to wod, 89 ðæt ic ðy ðeah andswarode on ðis gemet: 90 "Saga me ðu nu, hwelcne goldhord wolde 91 ðin Drihten habban æt sancte Petre 92 ða he him ða hehstan heofona rice 93 sealde to gewealde? Gewiss he nolde 94 elles wiht buton ðis word ane: 95 'Folgað me'."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Né Pier né li altri tolsero a Matia 95 oro od argento, quando fu sortito 96 al loco che perdé l’anima ria.
query.result:
**English:**
94 Neither Peter nor the others took from Matthias 95 gold or silver, when he was chosen 96 for the place that the wicked soul lost.
**Old English:**
94 Ne Petrus ne ða oðre ne namon Matian 95 gold ne seolfor, ða he gecoren wæs 96 to ðære stowe ðe ða synfullan sawle forleosan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Però ti sta, ché tu se’ ben punito; 98 e guarda ben la mal tolta moneta 99 ch’esser ti fece contra Carlo ardito.
query.result:
**English:**
97 Therefore, stay where you are, for you are well punished; 98 and look well at the ill-gotten money 99 that made you so bold against Charles.
**Old English:**
97 Forðæm ðu wuna ðær, forðæm ðu eart wel gewrecen; 98 and beheald ða yfle genumene feoh 99 ðe ðe dyde ðæt ðu wære wid Carolus dyrstig.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 E se non fosse ch’ancor lo mi vieta 101 la reverenza de le somme chiavi 102 che tu tenesti ne la vita lieta,
103 io userei parole ancor più gravi; 104 ché la vostra avarizia il mondo attrista, 105 calcando i buoni e sollevando i pravi.
query.result:
**English:**
100 And if it were not that reverence for the highest keys 101 which you held in your happy life still forbids me,
102 I would use even graver words; 103 for your avarice saddens the world, 104 trampling on the good and exalting the wicked.
**Old English:**
100 And gif hit nære ðæt ða hehstan teonæ 101 ðe ðu hæfde on ðinum life liðan,
102 ic wolde ðe mid wordum wærlicor 103 ðin ofermetto eac mænan; 104 forðæm ðe ðin gitsung ðone grund sceððeð, 105 ðone godan forwyrnd and ðone yflan up ahefð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Fatto v’avete dio d’oro e d’argento; 113 e che altro è da voi a l’idolatre, 114 se non ch’elli uno, e voi ne orate cento?
115 Ahi, Costantin, di quanto mal fu matre, 116 non la tua conversion, ma quella dote 117 che da te prese il primo ricco patre!».
query.result:
**English:**
112 You have made yourselves a god of gold and silver; 113 and what difference is there between you and the idolaters, 114 except that they worship one, and you a hundred?
115 Ah, Constantine, of how much evil was your conversion the mother, 116 not your conversion, but that dowry 117 which the first wealthy pope received from you!
**Old English:**
112 Ge geworhton eow god of golde and of seolfre; 113 and hwæt is elles betwux eow and ðam hæðenum, 114 buton ðæt hi anbiddað ænne, and ge anbiddað hundteontig?
115 Eala, Constantinus, of hu miclum yfele wære ðin gecyrrednes modor, 116 na ðin gecyrrednes, ac seo gifu 117 ðe se forma ricesta papa of ðe onfeng!

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 E mentr’ io li cantava cotai note, 119 o ira o coscïenza che ’l mordesse, 120 forte spingava con ambo le piote.
query.result:
**English:**
118 And while I sang such notes to him, 119 either anger or conscience that bit him, 120 he pushed hard with both his paws.
**Old English:**
118 And ða ic him sang swylce gydda, 119 oððe yrre oððe inwit ðæt hine wætte, 120 stiðe he hine stange mid ðam twegen fotum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 I’ credo ben ch’al mio duca piacesse, 122 con sì contenta labbia sempre attese 123 lo suon de le parole vere espresse.
query.result:
**English:**
121 I believe that my guide was pleased, 122 with such a contented expression he listened 123 to the sound of the true words expressed.
**Old English:**
121 Ic gelyfe wel ðæt ðam lærendum licode, 122 mid swilcum bliðum andwlitan he æfre geaðmodode 123 ðone stefn ðara soðra worda gesæd.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Però con ambo le braccia mi prese; 125 e poi che tutto su mi s’ebbe al petto, 126 rimontò per la via onde discese.
query.result:
**English:**
124 Therefore with both arms he seized me; 125 and after he had me all to his chest, 126 he climbed back up the way he had come down.
**Old English:**
124 Þa he mid ðam twam earmum me gefeng; 125 and ða he me ealne to his breostum hefde, 126 he eft up astah ðone weg ðe he ær of com.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Né si stancò d’avermi a sé distretto, 128 sì men portò sovra ’l colmo de l’arco 129 che dal quarto al quinto argine è tragetto.
query.result:
**English:**
127 Nor did he tire of holding me close to him, 128 so he carried me over the summit of the arch 129 that is spanned from the fourth to the fifth embankment.
**Old English:**
127 Ne wearð he ðæs gewemmed ðæt he mec wið hine hæfde, 128 ac he mec bær ofer ðæs bogan hrycg 129 ðe of ðam feorðan wealle to ðam fiftan stent.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Quivi soavemente spuose il carco, 131 soave per lo scoglio sconcio ed erto 132 che sarebbe a le capre duro varco.
query.result:
**English:**
130 There he gently lowered his burden, 131 gently over the rough and steep cliff 132 that would be a hard passage even for goats.
**Old English:**
130 Þær he softe alihte of his byrðene, 131 softe for ðam stiðe and ðam steapan clife 132 ðe wäre geatum ungemete earfoð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 Indi un altro vallon mi fu scoperto.
query.result:
**English:**
133 Then another valley was revealed to me.
**Old English:**
133 Þa wæs ðær an oðer dal gesewen.
